text: The 1984–85 season was the 88th season of competitive football in Scotland. This is the last time a non-Old Firm club has won the Scottish Premier title. ==Scottish Premier Division== Champions: Aberdeen Relegated: Dumbarton, Morton. ==Scottish League Division One== Promoted: Motherwell, Clydebank Relegated: Meadowbank Thistle, St Johnstone (The first team to be relegated in successive seasons) ==Scottish League Division Two== Promoted: Montrose, Alloa Athletic ==Other honours== ===Cup honours=== {| class="wikitable" style="text- align: center;" |- !width=140|Competition !width=135|Winner !width=80|Score !width=135|Runner-up |- |align=left|Scottish Cup 1984–85 |Celtic |2 – 1 |Dundee United |- |align=left|League Cup 1984–85 |Rangers |1 – 0 |Dundee United |- |align=left|Youth Cup |Aberdeen |5 – 3 |Celtic |- |align=left|Junior Cup |Pollok |3 – 1 |Petershill |} ===Individual honours=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! width=170|Award ! width=150|Winner ! width=140|Club |- | Footballer of the Year || Hamish McAlpine || Dundee United |- |Players' Player of the Year || Jim Duffy || Morton |- |Young Player of the Year || Craig Levein || Heart of Midlothian |} ==Scotland national team== {| class="wikitable" !Date !Venue !Opponents ! !Competition !Scotland scorer(s) |-bgcolor=#ddffdd |12 September 1984 |Hampden Park, Glasgow (H) | Yugoslavia |align=center|6–1 |Friendly |Davie Cooper, Graeme Souness, Kenny Dalglish, Paul Sturrock, Maurice Johnston, Charlie Nicholas |-bgcolor=#ddffdd |17 October 1984 |Hampden Park, Glasgow (H) | Iceland |align=center|3–0 |WCQG7 |Paul McStay (2), Charlie Nicholas |-bgcolor=#ddffdd |14 November 1984 |Hampden Park, Glasgow (H) | Spain |align=center|3–1 |WCQG7 |Maurice Johnston (2), Kenny Dalglish |-bgcolor=#ffdddd |27 February 1985 |Estadio Sanchez Pizjuan, Seville (A) | Spain |align=center|0–1 |WCQG7 | |-bgcolor=#ffdddd |27 March 1985 |Hampden Park, Glasgow (H) | Wales |align=center|0–1 |WCQG7 | |-bgcolor=#ddffdd |25 May 1985 |Hampden Park, Glasgow (H) | England |align=center|1–0 |Rous Cup |Richard Gough |-bgcolor=#ddffdd |28 May 1985 |Laugardalsvollur, Reykjavík (A) | Iceland |align=center|1–0 |WCQG7 |Jim Bett |} Key: *(H) = Home match *(A) = Away match *WCQG7 = World Cup qualifying - Group 7 ==See also== 1984–85 Aberdeen F.C. season ==Notes and references== Category:Seasons in Scottish football
title: 1984–85 in Scottish football
